segment.source: Securing End-to-End IPsec Connections by Using IKEv2 in Windows Server 2012 (Windows 10)
segment.target: Securing End-to-End IPsec Connections by Using IKEv2 in Windows Server 2012 (Windows 10)

segment.source: Securing End-to-End IPsec Connections by Using IKEv2 in Windows Server 2012
segment.target: Securing End-to-End IPsec Connections by Using IKEv2 in Windows Server 2012

segment.source: Securing End-to-End IPsec connections by using IKEv2
segment.target: Securing End-to-End IPsec connections by using IKEv2

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: IKEv2 offers the following:
segment.target: IKEv2 offers the following:

segment.source: Supports IPsec end-to-end transport mode connections
segment.target: Supports IPsec end-to-end transport mode connections

segment.source: Provides interoperability for Windows with other operating systems that use IKEv2 for end-to-end security
segment.target: Provides interoperability for Windows with other operating systems that use IKEv2 for end-to-end security

segment.source: Supports Suite B (RFC 4869) requirements
segment.target: Supports Suite B (RFC 4869) requirements

segment.source: Coexists with existing policies that deploy AuthIP/IKEv1
segment.target: Coexists with existing policies that deploy AuthIP/IKEv1

segment.source: Uses the Windows PowerShell interface exclusively for configuration.
segment.target: Uses the Windows PowerShell interface exclusively for configuration.

segment.source: You cannot configure IKEv2 through the user interface.
segment.target: You cannot configure IKEv2 through the user interface.

segment.source: Uses certificates for the authentication mechanism
segment.target: Uses certificates for the authentication mechanism

segment.source: You can use IKEv2 as a virtual private network (VPN) tunneling protocol that supports automatic VPN reconnection.
segment.target: You can use IKEv2 as a virtual private network (VPN) tunneling protocol that supports automatic VPN reconnection.

segment.source: IKEv2 allows the security association to remain unchanged despite changes in the underlying connection.
segment.target: IKEv2 allows the security association to remain unchanged despite changes in the underlying connection.

segment.source: In this document
segment.target: In this document

segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.target: Devices joined to a domain

segment.source: Note: This topic includes sample Windows PowerShell cmdlets.
segment.target: Note: This topic includes sample Windows PowerShell cmdlets.

segment.source: For more info, see How to Run a Windows PowerShell Cmdlet.
segment.target: For more info, see How to Run a Windows PowerShell Cmdlet.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: These procedures assume that you already have a public key infrastructure (PKI) in place for device authentication.
segment.target: These procedures assume that you already have a public key infrastructure (PKI) in place for device authentication.

segment.source: Devices joined to a domain
segment.target: Devices joined to a domain

segment.source: The following Windows PowerShell script establishes a connection security rule that uses IKEv2 for communication between two computers (CLIENT1 and SERVER1) that are joined to the corp.contoso.com domain as shown in Figure 1.
segment.target: The following Windows PowerShell script establishes a connection security rule that uses IKEv2 for communication between two computers (CLIENT1 and SERVER1) that are joined to the corp.contoso.com domain as shown in Figure 1.

segment.source: the contoso corporate network
segment.target: the contoso corporate network

segment.source: Figure 1 The Contoso corporate network
segment.target: Figure 1 The Contoso corporate network

segment.source: This script does the following:
segment.target: This script does the following:

segment.source: Creates a security group called IPsec client and servers and adds CLIENT1 and SERVER1 as members.
segment.target: Creates a security group called IPsec client and servers and adds CLIENT1 and SERVER1 as members.

segment.source: Creates a Group Policy Object (GPO) called IPsecRequireInRequestOut and links it to the corp.contoso.com domain.
segment.target: Creates a Group Policy Object (GPO) called IPsecRequireInRequestOut and links it to the corp.contoso.com domain.

segment.source: Sets the permissions to the GPO so that they apply only to the computers in IPsec client and servers and not to Authenticated Users.
segment.target: Sets the permissions to the GPO so that they apply only to the computers in IPsec client and servers and not to Authenticated Users.

segment.source: Indicates the certificate to use for authentication.
segment.target: Indicates the certificate to use for authentication.

segment.source: Important: The certificate parameters that you specify for the certificate are case sensitive, so make sure that you type them exactly as specified in the certificate, and place the parameters in the exact order that you see in the following example.
segment.target: Important: The certificate parameters that you specify for the certificate are case sensitive, so make sure that you type them exactly as specified in the certificate, and place the parameters in the exact order that you see in the following example.

segment.source: Failure to do so will result in connection errors.
segment.target: Failure to do so will result in connection errors.

segment.source: Creates the IKEv2 connection security rule called My IKEv2 Rule.
segment.target: Creates the IKEv2 connection security rule called My IKEv2 Rule.

segment.source: powershell logoWindows PowerShell commands
segment.target: powershell logoWindows PowerShell commands

segment.source: Type each cmdlet on a single line, even though they may appear to wrap across several lines because of formatting constraints.
segment.target: Type each cmdlet on a single line, even though they may appear to wrap across several lines because of formatting constraints.

segment.source: Devices not joined to a domain
segment.target: Devices not joined to a domain

segment.source: Use a Windows PowerShell script similar to the following to create a local IPsec policy on the devices that you want to include in the secure connection.
segment.target: Use a Windows PowerShell script similar to the following to create a local IPsec policy on the devices that you want to include in the secure connection.

segment.source: Important: The certificate parameters that you specify for the certificate are case sensitive, so make sure that you type them exactly as specified in the certificate, and place the parameters in the exact order that you see in the following example.
segment.target: Important: The certificate parameters that you specify for the certificate are case sensitive, so make sure that you type them exactly as specified in the certificate, and place the parameters in the exact order that you see in the following example.

segment.source: Failure to do so will result in connection errors.
segment.target: Failure to do so will result in connection errors.

segment.source: powershell logoWindows PowerShell commands
segment.target: powershell logoWindows PowerShell commands

segment.source: Type each cmdlet on a single line, even though they may appear to wrap across several lines because of formatting constraints.
segment.target: Type each cmdlet on a single line, even though they may appear to wrap across several lines because of formatting constraints.

segment.source: Make sure that you install the required certificates on the participating computers.
segment.target: Make sure that you install the required certificates on the participating computers.

segment.source: Note:
segment.target: Note:

segment.source: For local devices, you can import the certificates manually if you have administrator access to the computer.
segment.target: For local devices, you can import the certificates manually if you have administrator access to the computer.

segment.source: For more info, see Import or export certificates and private keys.
segment.target: For more info, see Import or export certificates and private keys.

segment.source: You need a root certificate and a computer certificate on all devices that participate in the secure connection.
segment.target: You need a root certificate and a computer certificate on all devices that participate in the secure connection.

segment.source: Save the computer certificate in the Personal/Certificates folder.
segment.target: Save the computer certificate in the Personal/Certificates folder.

segment.source: For remote devices, you can create a secure website to facilitate access to the script and certificates.
segment.target: For remote devices, you can create a secure website to facilitate access to the script and certificates.

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.source: Follow these procedures to verify and troubleshoot your IKEv2 IPsec connections:
segment.target: Follow these procedures to verify and troubleshoot your IKEv2 IPsec connections:

segment.source: Use the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security snap-in to verify that a connection security rule is enabled.
segment.target: Use the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security snap-in to verify that a connection security rule is enabled.

segment.source: Open the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security console.
segment.target: Open the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security console.

segment.source: In the left pane of the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security snap-in, click Connection Security Rules, and then verify that there is an enabled connection security rule.
segment.target: In the left pane of the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security snap-in, click Connection Security Rules, and then verify that there is an enabled connection security rule.

segment.source: Expand Monitoring, and then click Connection Security Rules to verify that your IKEv2 rule is active for your currently active profile.
segment.target: Expand Monitoring, and then click Connection Security Rules to verify that your IKEv2 rule is active for your currently active profile.

segment.source: Use Windows PowerShell cmdlets to display the security associations.
segment.target: Use Windows PowerShell cmdlets to display the security associations.

segment.source: Open a Windows PowerShell command prompt.
segment.target: Open a Windows PowerShell command prompt.

segment.source: Type get-NetIPsecQuickModeSA to display the Quick Mode security associations.
segment.target: Type get-NetIPsecQuickModeSA to display the Quick Mode security associations.

segment.source: Type get-NetIPsecMainModeSA to display the Main Mode security associations.
segment.target: Type get-NetIPsecMainModeSA to display the Main Mode security associations.

segment.source: Use netsh to capture IPsec events.
segment.target: Use netsh to capture IPsec events.

segment.source: Open an elevated command prompt.
segment.target: Open an elevated command prompt.

segment.source: At the command prompt, type netsh wfp capture start.
segment.target: At the command prompt, type netsh wfp capture start.

segment.source: Reproduce the error event so that it can be captured.
segment.target: Reproduce the error event so that it can be captured.

segment.source: At the command prompt, type netsh wfp capture stop.
segment.target: At the command prompt, type netsh wfp capture stop.

segment.source: A wfpdiag.cab file is created in the current folder.
segment.target: A wfpdiag.cab file is created in the current folder.

segment.source: Open the cab file, and then extract the wfpdiag.xml file.
segment.target: Open the cab file, and then extract the wfpdiag.xml file.

segment.source: Open the wfpdiag.xml file with your an XML viewer program or Notepad, and then examine the contents.
segment.target: Open the wfpdiag.xml file with your an XML viewer program or Notepad, and then examine the contents.

segment.source: There will be a lot of data in this file.
segment.target: There will be a lot of data in this file.

segment.source: One way to narrow down where to start looking is to search the last “errorFrequencyTable” at the end of the file.
segment.target: One way to narrow down where to start looking is to search the last “errorFrequencyTable” at the end of the file.

segment.source: There might be many instances of this table, so make sure that you look at the last table in the file.
segment.target: There might be many instances of this table, so make sure that you look at the last table in the file.

segment.source: For example, if you have a certificate problem, you might see the following entry in the last table at the end of the file:
segment.target: For example, if you have a certificate problem, you might see the following entry in the last table at the end of the file:

segment.source: In this example, there are 32 instances of the ERRORIPSECIKENOCERT error.
segment.target: In this example, there are 32 instances of the ERRORIPSECIKENOCERT error.

segment.source: So now you can search for ERRORIPSECIKENOCERT to get more details regarding this error.
segment.target: So now you can search for ERRORIPSECIKENOCERT to get more details regarding this error.

segment.source: You might not find the exact answer for the issue, but you can find good hints.
segment.target: You might not find the exact answer for the issue, but you can find good hints.

segment.source: For example, you might find that there seems to be an issue with the certificates, so you can look at your certificates and the related cmdlets for possible issues.
segment.target: For example, you might find that there seems to be an issue with the certificates, so you can look at your certificates and the related cmdlets for possible issues.
